instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
having this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board, fan spins but check no CPUVOCORE.
traced down and found <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is missing

think CPU vcore won't come out if <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> missing.

checked on <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>, pin 13 14 =5v, pin3(en)=3v

all look good, but no output <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>, then replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> <TRANSISTOR>Q7635</TRANSISTOR>
but no change.

any advice?

thanks

threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R1305</RESISTOR>=0 oh <RESISTOR>R1306</RESISTOR>=0 oh ( schematics says 10,but i checked on another working board,they are all 0 too)
traces to resistors connected to <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> are all good

and idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: No idea. Badly soldered <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> or bad CPU, the CPU is supplying the feedback in this circuit.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
already replaced <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> ,so.. only thing left is the CPU?
ever try to reball this model with success?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: And what makes you thing <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> replacement was successful? Replacing CPU is a waste of time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: it was pretty easy to replace... and i replaced twice <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> already

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Not much left then besides a dead CPU. Check the coil and cap just to be sure, but they never fail.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No Title

IT IS THE CPU.  hate doing it, but no other way around when I have to get the job done.
pull the CPU from another bad board, reballed and soldered on , spent almost an hour on it then it works now. testing it.

threads.message: thanks again man, appreciate the hint
